ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed knowledge in Ancient Roman history and historiography and skills in historical writing.
I learned some Roman history, but, more importantly, I learned how to read critically and contextualize an author in the broader intellectual conversation.
A lot about Edward Gibbon, his contemporaries, and the Roman Empire

I learned how to read and analyze classical texts, speak eloquently about various works, and engage in meaningful research about Roman history. Additionally, the required writing enabled me to explore my unique interests and mesh literary and historical analysis. The course delves into the study of Roman history and serves as a perfect introduction to high level studies of classics and history.
Ive become a much more capable writer, thinker, and speaker as a result of this class

-Critical analysis of historical texts
-Writing at a college level
-Going beyond just observations within writings
-Dealing with a lot of pages of text (many times 75-100 per class)
-Understanding the source material (Gibbon) across the semester, in order to form a deliberate and well-thought final paper
-Longer form writing than high school (the final paper is ~4500 words)
-Reading footnotes is key! The skill of not just taking the author's word for it! Gibbon may be wrong sometimes!
Learned a lot about both history and English and detailed readings
I learned a lot about the decline and fall of the Roman Empire and how history is represented in general, as well as an understanding of Edward Gibbon.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is taught well and enthusiastically by Rafail and Professor Johnston. The course does not assume any knowledge on the Roman empire by students but can become hard to understand or grasp without prior knowledge of the era.

The course is well organized, and the professor and the TA are both accessible and eager to help students. The professor's thoughtful individualized feedback on each assignment allows students to gauge their progress in the course.

The course did not go over enough actual Roman history

I was interested in learning more about it, and yes I did, but there was a big gap in knowledge since we would jump into reading Edward Gibbon and assessing his writing and the events of the Roman Empire he wrote about,  while I would be lost on names of random emperors and events.

+ kinda lack of accessibility since some students knew a lot about classics and Roman history, they led the class a lot, which was interesting to hear but sometimes a bit confusing. Coming from a disadvantaged public high school where I didnt read classics and etc. i felt a bit discouraged when not understanding what they were talking about or referencing, and I dont think I was alone in that.

Class couldve been more personal as well. Great, sweet Professor, and same with the TA. However the class wasnt very close, we kinda just came, discussed a bit, then left. Couldve been a better facilitated discussion. 
Couldve left even more knowledge if there was a breakdown of the history alongside every seminar.

The course was outstanding overall! The readings were fascinating and meaningful, the discussions were engaging and enlightening, and Professor Johnston is an incredible teacher. Towards the end of the course, students seemed less interested in the material, which may be explained by a less discussion-based learning system that we approached near the closure of the course. Despite this minor detail, I'm very impressed and thrilled that I took this course.

Strengths: Outstanding Professor, great syllabus 
Weaknesses: Could have used more discussion at times  occasionally would become slightly too lectury

Strengths:
-Seminar format, the discussions were excellent, and really well guided by Professor Johnston. He gave a large amount of freedom in the discussion paths, but also contributed a lot of wisdom to the discussion
-Writing, Professor Johnston and Rafail gave in depth feedback to our responses, which really helped me to further develop my ideas and reasonings for arguments.
-Gibbon's Decline and Fall was a perfect text for analysis. Its length makes it appropriate for a full-term course (and we still read the abridged version), but it also covers such a vast range of events that it never becomes dull. Gibbon is insightful, witty, and deep on every single page. You could easily fill several discussions with every section of Gibbon that we read.

Weaknesses:
-Diversity: the classics is more of a male dominated space. I don't like looking at things racially either, since that can become problematic, but it is also a very white/asian dominated space as well. This class was all men, it would have been nice to have some women. I know there are several prominent women in the classics space (Mary Beard comes to mind), so perhaps there may be growing interest from women in the area.  I liked how we discussed in the course about how Gibbon showed prejudice with "Orientalism" (i.e. looking at Near-Eastern peoples as languid and decadent), and "Barbarianism" (looking at Northern European/Hunnic/Slavic peoples as savage), and also how Tacitus's Germania helped prop up the Nazi regime's claim to certain territories, and the idea of the Aryan race. I think it was fascinating to learn how the Classics can be both beneficial to society, allowing the continuation of literary traditions, and learning from the mistakes of our ancestors, but also how it can be abused to prop up nationalistic ideologies (this is not just European, Japan and China come to mind for empires that used the classics to provide cassi belli for expansion); which makes it important for the people of the classics to maintain the "beneficial" form. I don't think the lack of women detracted from the course, it was excellent, but their presence may have added several more insightful ideas.
Extremely well taught course, no weaknesses
It was a great course. The only improvement would be making it more than explicitly clear the nature of taking a course over 1 book.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes - this course is a good first-year seminar, a good way to learn about a big part of history, and also strengthen one's manner of looking at the world, without any stakes.
I would recommend this course to any first-year who is seeking a seminar experience.

Absolutely! The course itself was organized and student-focused, which facilitates learning. Also, if you ever get the chance to take a course with Professor Johnston, you should certainly do so. He's a wonderful professor who's especially energized by Roman history.
Absolutely. Great class, great professor, great content

I would certainly recommend this course to any student who is interested in history, especially of Rome, and in critical analysis of historical texts. Gibbon was such a charm to read, and every page of his is vibrant and overflowing with wit and character. The critical analysis of Gibbon is key; we learn not just about Roman history, but also how Gibbon's views shaped that history. We spent a lot of time discovering Gibbon's motives and biases, including reading his autobiography, and supplementary texts on Gibbon. These texts (Momigliano, Lieberman, and Woodhuysen especially), really illuminated who Gibbon was, and added a lot more depth to the reading of the Decline and Fall.
Yes for sure if they are prepared for a lot of writing
Yes, it is a good course, just understand what it means to take a course over 1 book.
Yes. Fantastic first year seminar
